Summary: Foundation model sold and hosted by AWS
Description: Model where the provider has no access to prompts or completions. AWS owns the deployment account and operates the infrastructure. Examples: Amazon Nova, Meta Llama, Google Gemma, DeepSeek.

Summary: Third-party model requiring vendor's EULA
Description: Model where data is processed in AWS infrastructure but the contract is with the vendor. Requires accepting vendor's End User License Agreement. Examples: Anthropic Claude, Twelve Labs, Writer AI.

Summary: Contract addendum for personal data processing
Description: Legal document defining roles (controller/processor), purposes, security measures, sub-processors, breach notification requirements, and transfer mechanisms (e.g., SCCs) for personal data processing under GDPR.

Summary: EU-approved cross-border transfer clauses
Description: Pre-approved contractual clauses by the European Commission enabling lawful transfers of personal data from EEA to third countries with required safeguards and obligations.

Summary: ISO 42001 management system for AI governance
Description: Management system defined in ISO/IEC 42001:2023 for governing the full AI lifecycle including risk assessment, controls, documentation, and continuous improvement.

Summary: EU regulation for personal data protection
Description: EU regulation 2016/679 governing the processing of personal data of EU residents. Requires lawful basis, data minimization, purpose limitation, and cross-border transfer safeguards.

Summary: EU regulation for AI system risk classification
Description: EU regulation 2024/1689 establishing rules for AI systems based on risk classification: prohibited, high-risk, limited-risk, and minimal-risk. Requires transparency, documentation, and human oversight for high-risk systems.

Summary: International standard for AI management systems
Description: International standard specifying requirements for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and improving an AI Management System (AIMS). Covers organizational context, leadership, planning, support, operations, performance evaluation, and improvement.

Summary: Contract defining software/model usage terms
Description: Legal agreement between licensor and user defining terms of use, restrictions, acceptable use policies, and liabilities for software or AI models. Required for vendor-sold models on Bedrock.

Summary: Geographic data storage and processing requirement
Description: Compliance requirement that data must be stored and processed within specific geographic boundaries (e.g., EU-only, single region). Critical for GDPR and sector-specific regulations.

Summary: EU AI Act classification requiring conformity assessment
Description: AI system classified under EU AI Act as high-risk, requiring conformity assessment, technical documentation, human oversight, and risk management. Examples: employment decisions, credit scoring, law enforcement.

Summary: Documentation of model characteristics and limitations
Description: Structured documentation describing a model's intended use cases, performance metrics, known limitations, training data characteristics, and ethical considerations. Required for transparency under EU AI Act.

Summary: AWS Bedrock content filtering and safety controls
Description: AWS Bedrock feature enabling content filtering, topic blocking, PII detection, and safety controls on model inputs and outputs. Supports EU AI Act human oversight requirements.

Summary: Processing requests across multiple AWS regions
Description: AWS Bedrock feature routing requests across up to 3 regions (us-east-2, eu-west-1, ap-northeast-1) for increased throughput and auto-failover. May impact strict data residency requirements.

Summary: AWS-managed account hosting foundation models
Description: AWS-owned and operated account in each Bedrock region containing deployed foundation models. Model providers have no access to these accounts, ensuring data isolation.

Summary: Non-content usage information shared with vendors
Description: Usage telemetry shared with some vendors (e.g., Mistral): AWS Account ID, region, model ID, request count, token usage, timestamps. Does NOT include prompts, completions, or content.

Summary: HIPAA-required agreement for PHI handling
Description: Agreement required under HIPAA when a service provider handles Protected Health Information (PHI). Defines responsibilities for safeguarding PHI.

Summary: Terms defining prohibited model usage
Description: Policy defining prohibited uses of AI models, such as generating harmful content, illegal activities, or violating third-party rights. Required compliance for most Bedrock models.

Summary: Entity determining data processing purposes
Description: Under GDPR, the entity that determines the purposes and means of processing personal data. Typically the customer using Bedrock for their applications.

Summary: Entity processing data on controller's behalf
Description: Under GDPR, the entity that processes personal data on behalf of the controller. AWS acts as processor for Bedrock services under the AWS DPA.

Summary: EU AI Act compliance verification process
Description: Process required under EU AI Act for high-risk AI systems to verify compliance with requirements including risk management, data governance, documentation, and transparency.

Summary: AWS audit logging service
Description: AWS service providing governance, compliance, and audit logging for AWS account activity. Records API calls and events for Bedrock usage, supporting EU AI Act record-keeping requirements.

Summary: AWS monitoring and observability service
Description: AWS service for monitoring applications, responding to performance changes, and optimizing resource utilization. Used for Bedrock operational monitoring and ISO 42001 performance evaluation.

Summary: Model testing and assessment feature
Description: AWS Bedrock capability for testing model accuracy, bias, safety, and performance. Supports EU AI Act accuracy requirements and ISO 42001 AI system impact assessment.

Summary: AWS ML model deployment service
Description: AWS service for deploying pre-trained ML models including Hugging Face models. Alternative to Bedrock for models not directly available, covered by AWS DPA.

Summary: Human oversight in AI decision-making
Description: Practice of involving human review in AI system outputs, especially for high-stakes decisions. Required under EU AI Act for high-risk AI systems and supported by Bedrock Guardrails.

Summary: Transport Layer Security encryption protocol
Description: Cryptographic protocol for secure data transmission. All Bedrock data is encrypted in transit using TLS 1.2, ensuring confidentiality during API calls.

Summary: EU AI Act category requiring transparency
Description: AI systems under EU AI Act requiring specific transparency obligations (e.g., chatbots must disclose AI nature). Less stringent than high-risk but still regulated.

Summary: EU AI Act category with no specific requirements
Description: AI systems under EU AI Act posing minimal risk, subject only to voluntary codes of conduct. Examples: spam filters, AI-enabled video games.

Summary: EU AI Act category for banned AI applications
Description: AI systems banned under EU AI Act due to unacceptable risk: social scoring, real-time biometric identification in public spaces, manipulation techniques, exploitation of vulnerabilities.

Summary: Permissive model usage license
Description: License allowing broad use, modification, and distribution of AI models with minimal restrictions. Examples: Meta Llama Community License, Apache 2.0, MIT. Enables commercial use on Bedrock.

Summary: AI model developed by China-based company
Description: Foundation model created by companies headquartered in China (e.g., DeepSeek, MiniMax, Moonshot AI, Qwen). May require additional organizational policy review regardless of AWS hosting.

Summary: Third party processing data for processor
Description: Entity engaged by a data processor to process personal data on behalf of the controller. DPAs require disclosure and approval of sub-processors.
